values.alignmentText: Albania's .NET scene is outsourcing-focused, centered in Tirana; expect modest openings and EU projects, with some remote roles.
Albania offers modest 2D environmental artist pay aligned with local cost of living. Remote roles can boost total compensation for a two-adult family.
Albania has few dedicated 2D environmental art programs; most upskilling is online or via remote workshops; local options mainly cover fundamentals.
Albania has few dedicated 2D environmental art programs; most grads rely on short courses or general design/game art, with limited local mentorship.
In Albania, 2D environmental artist roles are rarely filled locally; remote/imported talent or EU freelancers are typical.
In Albania, English usage among 2D environmental artists is present but not universal; expect bilingual capability screening especially in Tirana studios.
Albania offers remote 2D environmental artist roles case-by-case. Expect mixed maturity; hybrid/onsite may be needed.
In Albania, 2D environmental artists are limited; mid-level talent dominates, and senior mentorship is often remote from EU studios.
In Albania (Tirana), 3D animator pay trails top markets by about 25-30%, but lower cost of living and lifestyle offsets help.
Albania (Tirana): only a couple of local 3D animation providers; advanced topics require remote/online study.
In Albania, 3D animation programs are limited; graduates often need mentorship and local studios for exposure (Tirana).
Albania: 3D animator roles are rarely filled locally; rely on remote or imported talent.
English is common in Albania's urban 3D studios (Tirana); client-facing roles favor bilingual Albanian/English candidates.
Albania (Tirana): remote 3D animator roles exist case-by-case; limited process maturity; hybrids common; reliable broadband helps.
Albania (Tirana) has a small 3D animation pool with sporadic local availability; expect aggressive sourcing or remote/contract hires.
Albania offers modest 3D character artist pay, about 25-30% below top markets. Lower cost of living and visa-friendly policies soften relocation.
Albania (Tirana): 3D character art continuing education is infrequent; few local providers, mostly ad-hoc mentorship, with reliance on online courses.
Albania has few formal 3D character art programs (mostly in Tirana); graduates have mixed readiness and often require mentoring.
In Albania, 3D character artist roles have shallow local pipelines; expect 6+ months. Leverage remote/global candidates and incentives.
Albania's IT scenes (Tirana) use English widely; many studios expect Albanian basics, so bilingual English/Albanian 3D artists are favored.
Albania (Tirana): remote 3D artist roles exist case-by-case; expect some on-site days; async workflows growing but not fully mature.
Albania's 3D character artist scene is small but growing. Tirana hosts budding studios, but senior talent is limited; expect remote hires or relocation.
Albania's accelerator scene is limited to small university labs and a few EU-funded programs; no dedicated game accelerators currently.
PM2.5 in Tirana (Albania) sits in the mid-teens with winter spikes; moderate pollution monthly; kids may need masks on bad days.
Albania (Tirana) has a handful of service studios but no major IP anchors; favorable for small teams, limited for large game studios.
Albania's secular state allows atheism with broad acceptance; secular families face modest social pressure amid Muslim and Orthodox communities.
Albania: EU monitoring supports reforms, yet government influence over media and courts persists; progressive families should monitor watchdog alerts.
Banking in Albania offers online banking and cards, but foreigners may face longer account setup; cash remains common with many small vendors.
Beaches along the Albanian Riviera (Dhermi/Himare/Saranda) are usable and scenic. Outside major resorts, services and cleanliness vary.
Trey and Sarah will find a few board game cafés in Tirana hosting nights; scene is nascent with limited shops.
In Albania, visible pressure to stay slim exists in schools and media; supportive communities and inclusive spaces help counter social comparisons.
Albania's economy is mixed; Tirana IT/outsourcing grows, tourism-sensitive sectors wobble—stay flexible, save, and lean on remote work.
Albania shows moderate cancer incidence; urban pollution and lifestyle factors require mitigation; encourage screening and universal healthcare access.
Albania's prisons, including Tirana facilities, show reform progress, but overcrowding persists. Oversight varies; risk remains moderate for families.
Albania's formal childcare is uneven; private options exist mainly in Tirana and costlier, so families lean on relatives and informal networks.
Tirana shows kid-friendly upgrades like playgrounds and car-free nights on Skanderbeg Square. Sidewalks and stroller access remain uneven.
In Albania, state childcare subsidies are modest; families largely pay private centers or rely on relatives.
In Albania (AL), visa families are largely excluded from childcare subsidies; expect private care with limited public support.
In Tirana, Albania, cafe culture and football anchor social life; hiking and seaside trips help newcomers fit in. Expats foster gaming and climbing groups.
Tirana, Albania hosts meetups a few times a year; online groups keep developers connected between gatherings.
In Albania (Tirana), public health messaging is uneven; we'll need to maintain routines and lean on universal care amid access gaps.
In Tirana, Albania, community living options are sporadic and rely on informal networks; stable family-focused programs are limited.
Albania CM pay trails top markets by ~25–30%. Local packages lean toward lower salaries with strong lifestyle perks in Tirana.
Albania offers sporadic community-manager trainings and local meetups; most learning remains self-directed, with remote options helping Trey's team.
Albania's CM education is limited; only short certificates exist in Tirana and a few universities, so grads typically need mentoring.
Albania's local market for Community Managers is shallow; expect 6+ months, but remote/global candidates can speed hiring.
In Albania, English is common among community managers, but client-facing roles favor bilingual Albanian speakers; look for dual-language candidates.
Albania's IT scene supports hybrid work; remote CM roles exist but often require occasional Tirana onsite and steady collaboration.
Tirana, Albania has a small community manager pool; availability is sporadic—plan aggressive sourcing or remote/outsourced hires.
Albania's besa hospitality is welcoming, but expats must take initiative to connect. Learning Albanian helps join locals through schools and clubs.
Albania's established studios pay a bit below top hubs; with low cost of living and remote options, it can work for this family.
Albania startup pay is modest; remote USD salaries with equity can approach global medians after cost of living, though equity liquidity remains uncertain.
Albania residency rules are complex; expect Albanian docs and translations, renewals, and local fees—legal counsel advised.
In Albania, local continuing education is limited; expect self-study and occasional regional workshops or travel for upskilling.
In Albania (Tirana), contractor benches exist but are modest; strong remote talent in IT, but lead times can occur.
In Albania, drug laws are strict; minor infractions can affect immigration records, with limited but available treatment options.
Albania offers affordable payroll and office space for software teams; Tirana IT talent is strong, but power reliability can affect operating costs.
Albania offers low costs (rent, groceries, services) vs the US; USD incomes can save well, but budget for utilities, internet, and currency shifts.
Tirana offers several coworking spaces and a budding startup scene, but game-dev labs (mocap/audio) are scarce.
Albania's IT sector is growing, but skilled devs remain competitive; expect hiring friction. Remote work and local grads help bridge the gap.
In Albania, mental health care access is variable. Stigma or limited providers can hinder family therapy access.
In Albania, social circles open slowly; persistence plus shared projects help deep bonds, with expat/community groups easing the path.
Albania shows evolving D&I: protections exist, but progress is uneven; rural areas lag in LGBTQ+ inclusion, while urban centers trend more open.
Albania's drug enforcement is generally targeted with occasional crackdowns. Urban areas may see street checks, but overall life remains stable.
Albania permits dual citizenship with residency/notification steps; you could retain US passports post-naturalization if you complete the process.
Albania's early-stage grants are modest ($5k-$25k). For Trey's game-dev startup, these seed MVPs but often need private funds or EU programs.
In Albania, local game funding is limited; founders in Tirana typically rely on remote investors and international grants.
Albania's GDP grows ~3% with tourism/remittances; wages are modest and cyclical. Startup grants and a developing tech scene support entrepreneurship.
Albania is a small, open economy with growing entrepreneurship and reforms; informality and bureaucracy still hinder steady family-focused plans.
Albania shows stable reforms with EU accession drive. Policy direction remains relatively predictable, though election cycles bring modest shifts.
Albania's education varies; public schools have gaps, so tutoring or private/international options help meet high standards.
Albania has several CS programs in Tirana, but game-focused curricula are limited; students will need extra industry training or bootcamps.
Albania (Tirana) offers some visa sponsorship in IT/intl firms, but quotas and bureaucracy mean offers may be uncertain for families.
Albania's indie game scene leans Unity (Tirana); Unreal exists but smaller; remote cross-training and online resources support mixed tooling.
Tirana, Albania offers parks and mild weather. Traffic pollution causes occasional alerts, so plan around air quality and waste management.
Albania (AL) personal tax tops at 23% for salaries above 200k ALL monthly. Remote US income would face around that rate.
Albania fall runs about 26°C in September to 15°C by November (79°F to 59°F). Mild with occasional rain, great for outdoor time with light layers.
In Albania, families enjoy strong networks and community ties, but formal services may require self-advocacy and waitlists; neighborhoods support family life.
Albania allows family reunification for spouses and minor children; apostille/translation required; processing may be slow.
Albania offers modest child benefits (~1,500 ALL/mo) and about 1 year of leave with partial pay, still behind EU norms and with access hurdles.
Albania provides modest family benefits; childcare subsidies are limited, so most costs remain private.
In Albania, visa holders have limited family benefits. Regular supports are largely unavailable to non-citizens.
In Albania's urban settings (Tirana/AL), tidy smart-casual helps you blend in. Casual wear is fine, but polished outfits suit work and social events.
In Albania's urban centers (e.g., Tirana), women's fashion is modern and diverse. Smaller towns are more conservative.
In Tirana, Albania, men mix smart-casual with streetwear; workplaces prefer modest attire; urban fashion is modern, not flamboyant.
In Albania, urban centers like Tirana support women in tech, but traditional dress norms and family expectations still exert subtle pressure.
Albania's strict licensing and safe-storage rules limit gun ownership; for a family, public exposure feels low but stay aware.
Albania's consent norms vary; in Tirana, expect mixed awareness, prioritize explicit check-ins and clear safety plans.
Tirana hosts a modest founder scene with occasional meetups; cross-city mentorship and robust VC activity remain limited in Albania.
Fresh options exist in Tirana's markets and shops; international ingredients are available, but specialty items are rarer outside central neighborhoods.
Albania's cities (Tirana in particular) are generally welcoming; with initiative, you will connect and build a steady, supportive neighborhood network.
Albania's game dev scene is small; few local employers, so remote work for foreign studios is common.
Albania tolerates gender diversity in private life, but legal recognition lags and public acceptance remains uneven; urban areas more welcoming.
Albania has anti-discrimination laws and rising female participation. Enforcement and pay gaps persist; leadership representation remains uneven.
In Albania, urban centers trend toward egalitarian parenting; your family's shared caregiving aligns with this, while rural pockets stay traditional.
Albania still shows traditional gender scripts in public spaces and dating scenes. Our progressive family may face puzzled looks in first approaches.
US citizens in Albania face a stable process but with periodic renewals; expect Albanian forms, notarized leases, and some in-person office visits.
Albania's summers are warming and floods occur in river basins. Coastal sea-level rise adds risk, but proactive planning minimizes disruption.
Albania offers limited startup visa routes. Processing times can be unpredictable, so plan for delays and potential relocation steps for your family.
In Tirana, neat, professional dress fits work and social life; there is no extreme grooming pressure. A practical, polished look suits this family in Albania.
In Albania (Tirana), openness varies; progressive circles exist, but institutions remain cautious, so multi-partner families must navigate discreetly.
Albania has universal coverage, but public hospitals face equipment/wait-time issues; families often use private clinics for timely pediatric care.
In Tirana, residence requires private insurance; English-speaking clinics exist, but care costs and admin for visa families add risk.
Albania offers affordable public universities; some English-taught programs exist; admissions can be competitive; scholarships help families.
Albania: foreigners can enroll in public universities but face higher tuition and language/admin hurdles; some English-taught programs exist.
In Albania, established studios hire slowly; local roles are scarce, with many openings filled via remote contractors.
Albania startups rely on remote/relocated staff; tapping global talent could speed Trey's game-dev hires and grant access.
Tirana has plentiful new apartments in family-friendly areas; quality varies and foreign mortgage access is limited, so renting is typically the practical path.
In Albania, e-filing exists mainly for businesses; individuals rely on accountants, with Albanian-only portals and shifting rules.
Albania generally welcomes foreigners; urban hubs ease integration and language learning. Some public discourse remains cautiously skeptical.
Reception in Albania varies by class and language; immerse in local life to avoid aloofness.
Albania: Public schooling is free to grade 9; upper secondary quality varies by city; informed families in Tirana often use private English schools.
In Albania, visa families can enroll in public schools. They face Albanian-language curricula and limited language support.
In Albania, Albanian dominates admin. Urban tech scenes use some English, but official forms require Albanian; commit to language study.
English is common in Albania's international studios for cross-border work; locals rely on Albanian for community and documentation.
Albania's startup scene relies on English for investors and platforms. Local Albanian fluency is needed for hiring and compliance.
Albania has only a few game-IP specialists; startups rely on referrals. Seek Tirana firms or regional IP clinics for publishing/licensing.
Pride marches in Tirana; legal protections exist, but social acceptance is uneven for LGBTQ+ families; plan safety for public displays.
Albania has few formal playtesting labs. Tirana indie groups lead ad hoc testing with online testers across Europe.
Albania treats Marxism as historical/academic; democracy governs policy, with open debate but limited mainstream influence.
Albania mixes tradition with growing openness; Trey's nurturing/entrepreneur role may face mild pushback in rural areas but gains acceptance in Tirana.
In Albania, mass violence is uncommon. Authorities communicate clearly and communities stay prepared.
Meetups exist but are concentrated in Tirana and require proactive outreach. Seek expat and local groups to build community.
Albania's 2024 min wage ~40,000 ALL (€340) monthly; far below subsistence for a four-person family, likely needing multiple jobs.
Albania's Tirana offers 100-200 Mbps fiber with decent gaming latency; outages outside the capital require backup gear.
In Albania, non-monogamy faces stigma and limited protections; openness may risk social backlash and civil/legal consequences, especially outside Tirana.
Albania values directness in professional talks, but politics and social topics can be sensitive. Read the room to avoid missteps.
Accursed Mountains and the Albanian Riviera offer dramatic hikes and blue seas. Theth/Valbonë and Dajti Park provide easy family-friendly trails.
Albania faces earthquake and flood risk (Durrës 2019); response varies by area, so prepare kits and drills and consider insurance.
Great nature access in Albania: beaches near Durres within 1-2 hours and family-friendly trails around Dajti; some hikes may need gear.
Nightlife in Tirana, Albania features pop/DJ nights and seasonal beach festivals; families should plan ahead for venues and occasional trips.
Nightlife exists mainly in Tirana's Blloku and a few districts; outside, options are sparse; plan babysitters and safe transport.
Albania's game dev scene is nascent. Tirana hosts occasional jams via ICT groups, but regular meetups and family-friendly events are rare.
Tirana has a handful of fledgling indie studios (e.g., Albanian Game Developers) with limited visibility. No major studios are headquartered here.
Albania shows moderate obesity levels; public health efforts plus family-friendly, active lifestyles help keep trends stable.
Albania offers low costs and Tirana's incubators for experimentation. However, robust funding and senior game talent are still scarce.
Tirana is lively, but Albania’s smaller towns like Shkodër or Korçë offer a café-paced rhythm that fits Sarah.
Tirana, Albania: parenting often involves grandparents; strong family input is common, while schools push balanced development and autonomy.
Albania naturalization typically requires 5 years of residence with language/integration checks. Dual citizenship is allowed; investment routes are narrow.
Albania's corruption is systemic; plan for bureaucratic delays and paperwork when engaging with public services.
Albania (Tirana) tends toward warm, close-contact culture; expect closer personal space in markets and transit—gently set boundaries.
Albania often uses close greetings like hugs or cheek kisses. For this family, cue before touch and offer space for the kids when needed.
Albania offers mild springs and autumns, with long pleasant windows. Summers near the coast are warm but manageable, while inland can be hotter.
Albania's parliament is competitive, but elites influence courts/media; robust watchdogs and EU reforms are key to resilience.
In Albania, polyamory has limited recognition and social stigma persists; expect low protections and potential housing or custody challenges.
Tirana offers public kindergartens with waitlists; private nurseries exist, but hours and costs vary, challenging dual-working families.
Tirana offers English-language private schools and Montessori options; outside the capital, choices thin and quality varies; verify accreditation.
Processed foods are common in Albania but balanced by strong fresh markets. Home cooking helps in Tirana and other urban areas.
In Albania (Tirana), PMM (Games) pay trails top markets by 25-30%. Remote work and lifestyle perks help offset the gap.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Albania has limited local continuing education for game product marketing; most learning is remote, with few in-person workshops (Tirana).

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Albania's product marketing for games is nascent; few dedicated PMM tracks exist (mostly in Tirana), with generic marketing programs and mentoring needed.
Albania PMM (Games) hiring: local pipelines are shallow; rely on remote/imported talent with global searches and flexible incentives.
Albania (Tirana): game marketing favors bilinguals; English is common in dev teams, Albanian helps with local campaigns.
Albania (Tirana): remote PM (Games) roles exist case-by-case; studios favor partial remote weeks with frequent onsite collaboration; broadband improving.
Albania's game PMM pool is small (Tirana); senior PMMs are scarce and studios few. Hiring may require aggressive sourcing or remote/contract PMMs.
In Albania, EU-aligned reform pace grows with urban Tirana; rural areas retain conservative norms, but progressive families push gradual change.
Albania is generally conservative; reputational risks exist for women or queer folks discussing partners. Urban Tirana is more tolerant than rural areas.
Albania's messaging emphasizes anti-corruption and EU readiness. It glosses governance gaps, but counterpoints remain accessible.
In Albania (AL), some state/oligarch framing exists. Independent outlets and media literacy help balance views.
Public transport in Tirana, Albania is workable but fragmented. Buses and minibuses exist, but schedules are informal and coverage is uneven.
Albania's publisher presence is limited. Engagement mainly comes from European events and remote outreach, not local BD teams.
In Albania (Tirana), high-end living is feasible but may require planning around limited providers and exclusive networks (private schools, clubs).
Albania offers affordable basics and healthcare; with budgeting this family can manage housing and essentials, though city housing may trade space for location.
Albania (Tirana): housing is affordable and services reasonable. With budgeting, a comfortable middle-income life is possible; plan for schooling and healthcare.
Albania's game scene leans toward real-time work. Cinematic pipelines are limited, but local partners support rapid prototyping.
Albania's secular constitution separates church and state; religion shapes culture but policy remains pluralistic and evidence-based.
Albania's established studios largely require onsite work; remote options exist, but are limited and often reserved for experienced roles.
Albania startups still favor on-site teams with limited hybrid options beyond leadership. That limits remote flexibility for Trey and Sarah.
Remote work exists in Tirana with coworking hubs such as Destil and Innospace, but power/broadband can be unstable outside the city; policies may need negotiation.
Albania mainly issues short-term permits (1–2 years) tied to work or business; renewals needed for longer stays.
Albania's growing startup scene offers grants and visas, but funding cycles cause churn; retaining senior engineers can be challenging.
In Albania, public pensions are modest; seniors often rely on family support or remittances.
Foreigners in Albania can contribute to the public pension with work; payouts are modest. For visa residents, private retirement savings remain essential.
Ruby roles in Albania are scarce; local shops favor PHP/Java/.NET. Sarah should target remote roles or diversify stacks.
Safe overall in Albania; violent crime is uncommon, but petty theft occurs in tourist zones; practice routine precautions and secure housing.
Several Tirana options exist (TIS, World Academy) with English instruction; private cost €8–12k/yr, while public schools are limited and require planning.
Albania's coast water is typically 22-26 C from May to Sept; July-Aug is warmest, shoulder months stay comfortable for kids with light rash guards.
Albania's climate is mild overall; hot summers inland and wet winters on the coast, with only occasional heat spikes or storms.
In Albania, long summer days and milder winters provide ample light; maintain energy with outdoor breaks and consistent routines.
Coastal Albania (Durres) offers mild winters and dry, warm summers. That suits the family's mild-weather preference with outdoor time most of the year.
Albania's Tirana tech scene has some senior leaders, but the pool is limited; startups typically recruit from abroad or remote to fill senior roles.
In urban Albania (Tirane), sex education is evolving; a sex-positive family may find more openness in cities, while rural areas stay conservative.
In Albania, healthcare is universal on paper, but funding gaps limit real access. Urban–rural disparities affect families.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: In Tirana, Albania, 2k sq ft rentals are tight; expect premium rents or broker help, with outer-neighborhood options near Grand Park.
Spring in Tirana, Albania, is comfortable 8–24 °C (46–75 °F) Mar–May; April rains and cooler inland mountains suit family-friendly mild weather.
Albania is generally stable with peaceful transitions; protests occur but are managed, with NATO support deterring regional risk.
Albania pursues pro-EU/NATO reforms with market focus; Tirana shows pluralism but polarization and media trust issues remain.
Albania's liberalizing market with informality; domestic demand is modest, reforms support entrepreneurship but safety nets and competition need strengthening.
Albania has a limited local game/animation studio scene; a few studios exist (primarily in Tirana), so remote collaboration is common.
Tirana, Albania: highs of 30-33 C with humidity. This is tolerable but above the family's ideal without coastal breezes.
In Tirana, Albania, proactive greetings yield friendly exchanges; English helps, and interactions tend to be positive when we initiate.
Albania offers no dedicated game tax credits; only small, uncertain culture subsidies with limited funding.
In Albania, permits typically take 2–3 months with fees around 70–90 EUR per applicant. For a family of four, costs stay budget-friendly.
Albania (AL): public trust in government remains low amid corruption concerns and slow reforms; transparency efforts exist but uneven.
In Albania, patronage and petty licensing bribes are common; expect bureaucratic delays—plan for thorough, documented, straightforward processes.
Tirana software salaries around €1,200–€1,800/mo; still below Western Europe, so remote work or dual income helps the family.
Albania weekends offer outdoor cafe culture, Adriatic coast trips (Durrës), and family meals; most shops open Saturday, many close Sunday afternoons.
Albania—schools typically end around 13:00. Trey's remote work helps bridge late afternoons, but wraparound care is variable, so paid helpers may be needed.
In Albania, annual leave is 20 days plus about 12 public holidays (roughly 32 total), aligning with a 30-day minimum and generally strong enforcement.
Albania offers around 20-24 paid vacation days plus holidays; family-friendly culture helps travel with kids, though long trips may need planning.
In Albania, vendor options are limited; a few Tirana-based studios handle art/QA, but core game-dev needs still rely on remote partners.
In Albania (Tirana), VFX real-time pay trails top markets by 25–30%; lifestyle and lower costs help offset the gap.
Albania (Tirana): VFX real-time education is limited; only a couple of local providers cover basics, with advanced topics mainly via remote study.
In Albania, VFX (real-time) education is nascent with few programs, mainly in Tirana. Most talent relies on on-the-job upskilling.
Tirana, Albania has shallow local VFX Real-Time pipelines; vacancies may stay open half a year or more; remote/global hiring can help.
English is common but not universal among Albania’s VFX real-time studios; many teams welcome bilingual skills and onboarding in Albanian.
Albania (Tirana) offers case-by-case remote real-time VFX; processes are still maturing, with onsite collaboration likely.
Albania's real-time VFX talent pool is small; Tirana has only a few local specialists outside main studios. Expect remote hiring or aggressive sourcing.
In Albania, relations with Kosovo are warm. Greece and Serbia are watched cautiously due to historical tensions.
Albania's resilient, hospitable self-view aligns with a family seeking community, strong education, and straightforward, welcoming governance amid reforms.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighbors Greece, North Macedonia, and Kosovo view Albania's reform path with cautious optimism; corruption concerns temper cross-border trust.
Albania provides residence permits for work, self-employment, and family reunification; remote-work options exist but are limited and require solid docs.
In Albania's cities (Tirana), sidewalks cover key zones but traffic can be brisk; for a family with kids, prioritize calm, park-adjacent neighborhoods.
Albania generally welcomes US migrants, especially in Tirana and coastal towns. Expats find active networks and broad English use, with some rural variation.
Albania's Bunk’Art bunkers turned art and Old Bazaar charm in Tirana invite curious family exploration; coastal towns add mild climate and hands-on culture.
Winters in Tirana, Albania are mild (3-13°C); snow is rare, so light coats and outdoor life stay comfortable.
Albania typically has a 40-hour workweek with remote/hybrid options. Occasional 42-45 hour sprints occur in outsourcing.
8: Albania (Tirana) supports family time with remote work and a slower pace; crunch periods exist, but recovery time is offered.
In Albania, labor laws protect contracts and overtime, but enforcement is patchy, especially in small firms.
